expanded_description: Who governs international trade? How do countries resolve trade disputes? What prevents a return to the protectionism of the 1930s? The answer lies in the World Trade Organization (WTO)—the international institution that sets the rules of global trade, provides a forum for negotiations, and resolves disputes between member countries. Founded in 1995 as the successor to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), the WTO has 164 members representing over 98% of world trade. Its core principles include non-discrimination (most-favored-nation and national treatment), reciprocity, transparency, and binding commitments. The WTO oversees the implementation of trade agreements, monitors national trade policies, and provides a dispute settlement mechanism that is binding and enforceable. Understanding the WTO is essential for analyzing the rules-based trading system, the benefits of multilateralism, and the challenges facing global trade governance.

core_concept.principle: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is the international organization that sets the rules for global trade and provides a forum for negotiating trade agreements and resolving disputes. It was established in 1995 as the successor to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), which had governed trade since 1947. The WTO has 164 members, accounting for over 98% of world trade. Its core objectives are to help trade flow as freely as possible, achieve further liberalization gradually through negotiation, and provide a mechanism for settling disputes impartially. The WTO is based on several key principles: (1) Non-discrimination: This has two components. Most-favored-nation (MFN) treatment requires that any advantage granted to one member must be granted to all members immediately and unconditionally. National treatment requires that imported goods be treated no less favorably than domestically produced goods once they have entered the market. (2) Reciprocity: Trade liberalization is negotiated on a reciprocal basis, with countries exchanging market access commitments. (3) Transparency: Members must publish their trade regulations and notify the WTO of changes. (4) Binding commitments: Members' tariff commitments are bound (maximum rates) and cannot be increased without compensating affected members. (5) Safety valves: Members can temporarily restrict trade under certain conditions (e.g., balance of payments difficulties, safeguard actions against import surges). The WTO's main functions include: administering trade agreements; providing a forum for trade negotiations; monitoring national trade policies through the Trade Policy Review Mechanism; providing technical assistance and training for developing countries; and cooperating with other international organizations. The crown jewel of the WTO is its dispute settlement mechanism. When a member believes another member has violated WTO rules, it can file a complaint. The process involves consultations, panel rulings, appeals (to the Appellate Body), and authorization of retaliation if the losing party does not comply. The system has handled over 600 disputes and is considered one of the most effective international dispute resolution mechanisms. However, the WTO faces challenges: the Doha Development Round of negotiations has stalled; the Appellate Body has been blocked by the U.S., impairing dispute settlement; rising protectionism and trade wars threaten the system; and new issues like e-commerce, digital trade, and climate change are not adequately covered. Despite these challenges, the WTO remains the foundation of the global trading system.
core_concept.explanation: Think of the WTO as the referee and rulebook for international trade. Before the WTO, trade was like a soccer game with no referee—countries could change the rules anytime, and disputes often led to retaliation and trade wars. The GATT/WTO system created a common rulebook (the agreements) and a referee (the dispute settlement system). Countries agree to follow the rules, and if they disagree, they go to the referee rather than fighting it out on the field. The system isn't perfect—the referee can be slow, and sometimes countries ignore the rules—but it's much better than the alternative. The WTO also provides a forum where countries negotiate new rules, like updating the rulebook for modern challenges.

sections.introduction: International trade doesn't happen in a vacuum. It is governed by a complex system of rules, agreements, and institutions. At the center of this system is the World Trade Organization (WTO)—the global body that sets the rules, monitors compliance, and resolves disputes. In this section, we'll explore the history, principles, functions, and challenges of the WTO. Understanding the WTO is essential for analyzing the rules-based trading system, the benefits of multilateralism, and the future of global trade governance.

key_concept.definition: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is an international organization that deals with the global rules of trade between nations. Its main functions are to administer trade agreements, provide a forum for trade negotiations, handle trade disputes, monitor national trade policies, and provide technical assistance to developing countries. The WTO was established on January 1, 1995, as the successor to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), which had governed trade since 1947. The WTO has 164 members, accounting for over 98% of world trade. Decisions are generally made by consensus among all members. The WTO is based on several core principles: (1) Most-favored-nation (MFN): Under the MFN principle, countries cannot normally discriminate between their trading partners. If a country grants a special favor (lower tariff, better treatment) to one trading partner, it must grant the same to all WTO members. This principle ensures that smaller countries are not disadvantaged. (2) National treatment: Imported goods must be treated no less favorably than domestically produced goods once they have entered the market. This prevents countries from using internal taxes or regulations to protect domestic industries after the border. (3) Reciprocity: Trade liberalization is negotiated on a reciprocal basis, with countries exchanging market access commitments. (4) Transparency: Members must publish their trade regulations and notify the WTO of changes, allowing other members to monitor compliance. (5) Binding commitments: Members' tariff commitments are bound—they cannot raise tariffs above bound rates without compensating affected members. (6) Safety valves: Members can temporarily restrict trade under certain conditions, such as balance of payments difficulties, safeguard actions against import surges, or for health and safety reasons. The WTO's dispute settlement mechanism is its most powerful feature. When a member believes another member has violated WTO rules, it can initiate dispute settlement. The process involves: consultations to reach a negotiated solution; if that fails, establishment of a panel to rule on the case; appeal to the Appellate Body (if functioning); and authorization of retaliation if the losing party does not comply. The system has handled over 600 disputes and is considered one of the most effective international legal systems. The WTO also conducts regular reviews of members' trade policies through the Trade Policy Review Mechanism, enhancing transparency. Developing countries receive special treatment, including longer timeframes to implement agreements and technical assistance. The WTO faces significant challenges: the Doha Development Round of negotiations, launched in 2001, has stalled; the Appellate Body has been blocked by the U.S. since 2019, crippling dispute settlement; rising protectionism and trade wars threaten the system; and new issues like digital trade, e-commerce, and climate change are not adequately addressed. Despite these challenges, the WTO remains the foundation of the global trading system.
key_concept.context: The WTO emerged from the post-World War II effort to create institutions for international economic cooperation, alongside the IMF and World Bank. The original idea was an International Trade Organization (ITO), but it failed to gain approval. Instead, the GATT provided a provisional framework that gradually expanded through eight rounds of negotiations, culminating in the Uruguay Round (1986-94) that created the WTO. The WTO expanded the GATT's scope to include services (GATS), intellectual property (TRIPS), and a stronger dispute settlement system. Recent decades have seen growing challenges to the WTO, including the rise of China, the stalemate in negotiations, and unilateral actions by major powers. In AP Macroeconomics, understanding the WTO is essential for analyzing the institutional framework of international trade.

classifications.behavior: The non-discrimination principles are the foundation of the WTO system. Most-favored-nation (MFN) requires that any advantage granted to one member must be granted to all members immediately and unconditionally. This means that if the EU lowers its tariff on Korean cars, it must lower it on Japanese, U.S., and all other WTO members' cars. MFN ensures that smaller countries are not disadvantaged and that trade relations are predictable. National treatment requires that imported goods be treated no less favorably than domestically produced goods once they have entered the market. This prevents countries from using internal taxes, regulations, or standards to protect domestic industries after the border. For example, a country cannot impose a higher sales tax on imported wine than on domestic wine. Exceptions to MFN are allowed for free trade agreements (like NAFTA/USMCA) and customs unions (like the EU), where members grant each other preferential treatment, and for special preferences for developing countries. These exceptions must meet WTO conditions to ensure they do not undermine the multilateral system.

image.alt: Diagram illustrating MFN (same treatment for all) and national treatment (equal treatment after border)
image.caption: Figure 10.4.4: Non-discrimination principles: MFN requires equal treatment for all members; national treatment requires equal treatment for imports after entry.

examples.explanation: When China joined the WTO in 2001, it received MFN treatment from all members, meaning its exports faced the same tariffs as any other member's exports. This contributed to China's trade boom.
A WTO case found that U.S. tax provisions favoring domestic companies over foreign companies violated national treatment, leading to changes in U.S. law.

classifications.value: Binding process for resolving trade disputes
classifications.behavior: The WTO's dispute settlement mechanism is often called the crown jewel of the system. It provides a structured, rules-based process for resolving trade conflicts, reducing the risk of unilateral retaliation and trade wars. The process has several stages: (1) Consultations: The complaining country requests consultations with the respondent to try to reach a negotiated solution. (2) Panel: If consultations fail, the complainant can request a panel of independent experts to rule on the case. The panel issues a report finding whether WTO rules were violated. (3) Appeal: Either party can appeal the panel's ruling to the Appellate Body, a standing body of seven judges. The Appellate Body can uphold, modify, or reverse the panel's legal findings. (4) Implementation: If the losing party is found to have violated rules, it must bring its measures into compliance. If it fails to do so within a reasonable period, it must negotiate compensation with the complainant. (5) Retaliation: If no compensation is agreed, the complainant can request authorization to retaliate by suspending concessions (imposing tariffs) equivalent to the damage caused. The system has handled over 600 disputes and has generally been effective in enforcing WTO rules. However, since 2019, the U.S. has blocked appointments to the Appellate Body, leaving it unable to hear appeals. This has crippled the dispute settlement system, as appeals now go into limbo.

image.alt: Flowchart showing stages of WTO dispute settlement: consultations, panel, appeal, implementation, retaliation
image.caption: Figure 10.4.5: The WTO dispute settlement process provides a structured mechanism for resolving trade conflicts.

examples.explanation: The U.S. has brought numerous cases against China alleging unfair trade practices, including export restraints, subsidies, and intellectual property violations. Many have been resolved through the WTO system.
The long-running dispute between the U.S. and EU over banana imports involved multiple WTO cases and authorized retaliation, eventually leading to a negotiated settlement.

classifications.behavior: WTO members periodically conduct rounds of negotiations to further liberalize trade and update the rules. The GATT/WTO has conducted nine rounds of negotiations. The early rounds focused on tariff reductions. The Kennedy Round (1964-67) included anti-dumping. The Tokyo Round (1973-79) addressed non-tariff barriers. The Uruguay Round (1986-94) was the most ambitious, creating the WTO, extending rules to services (GATS) and intellectual property (TRIPS), and strengthening dispute settlement. The current round, the Doha Development Round, was launched in 2001 with a focus on development issues, including agriculture, services, and special treatment for developing countries. The Doha Round has stalled due to disagreements between developed and developing countries on agriculture, industrial tariffs, and other issues. The consensus decision-making rule makes progress difficult with 164 members. The failure of the Doha Round has led to a proliferation of regional and bilateral trade agreements, as countries pursue liberalization outside the WTO framework.

image.caption: Figure 10.4.6: GATT/WTO negotiating rounds have progressively liberalized trade, though the Doha Round remains unfinished.

examples.explanation: The Uruguay Round (1986-94) was the most successful, creating the WTO, reducing tariffs by 40%, and extending rules to new areas. It took seven years to complete.
Launched in 2001, the Doha Round aimed to address developing country concerns. It has failed to reach agreement due to disagreements on agriculture, industrial tariffs, and other issues.

principles.principle: The WTO Provides a Rules-Based System That Reduces Uncertainty
principles.statement: Before the GATT/WTO system, trade relations were governed by bilateral agreements and power politics. Larger countries could pressure smaller ones, and disputes often led to retaliation and trade wars. The WTO replaced this with a rules-based system where all members, regardless of size, have equal rights and obligations. The MFN principle ensures predictability—countries know that their exports will face the same treatment as any other member's. Binding commitments (tariff bindings) mean that countries cannot arbitrarily raise tariffs. The transparency requirement allows members to monitor each other's policies. This predictability and transparency reduce uncertainty, encouraging investment and trade. Businesses can make long-term decisions knowing that the rules won't change arbitrarily. This is one of the WTO's greatest contributions to global economic stability.
principles.application: When analyzing the benefits of the WTO, emphasize the role of rules and predictability. The system reduces transaction costs and uncertainty, facilitating trade and investment. This is why businesses generally support the WTO and worry about its weakening.
principles.example: When China joined the WTO in 2001, it committed to binding tariffs and rule changes. This predictability encouraged foreign investment and helped China become the world's largest exporter. Companies invested in China confident that the rules would not change arbitrarily.

image.alt: Graph showing reduced trade policy uncertainty under WTO
image.caption: Figure 10.4.7: The WTO's rules-based system reduces uncertainty, encouraging trade and investment.

principles.principle: The Dispute Settlement Mechanism Prevents Trade Wars
principles.statement: One of the WTO's most important functions is providing a peaceful, orderly way to resolve trade disputes. Without it, countries might resort to unilateral retaliation, escalating into trade wars that harm everyone. The dispute settlement mechanism channels conflicts into a legal process with clear rules, impartial rulings, and authorized retaliation as a last resort. This reduces the risk of tit-for-tat escalation. Even when countries disagree with rulings, they generally comply because the alternative—a breakdown of the system—would be worse for everyone. The system has handled over 600 disputes and has generally been effective. However, the recent blockage of the Appellate Body has weakened the system, raising concerns about a return to unilateralism and trade wars.
principles.application: When evaluating the WTO's importance, consider the alternative. Without dispute settlement, trade conflicts would be resolved through power, not rules. Smaller countries would be disadvantaged, and disputes could escalate unpredictably. The system, though imperfect, is vastly preferable to the alternative.
principles.example: In the steel tariffs dispute of 2002, the EU and other countries challenged U.S. tariffs at the WTO. The WTO ruled against the U.S., which then removed the tariffs rather than face authorized retaliation. The dispute was resolved without a trade war.

image.alt: Diagram showing dispute resolution channeling conflict away from retaliation and trade wars
image.caption: Figure 10.4.8: The dispute settlement mechanism prevents trade wars by providing a peaceful, rules-based way to resolve conflicts.

principles.principle: The WTO Faces Significant Challenges That Threaten Its Effectiveness
principles.statement: Despite its achievements, the WTO faces serious challenges. (1) Stalled negotiations: The Doha Development Round, launched in 2001, has failed to reach agreement. Members disagree on agriculture, industrial tariffs, services, and other issues. The consensus decision-making rule makes progress difficult. (2) Blocked Appellate Body: Since 2019, the U.S. has blocked appointments to the Appellate Body, leaving it unable to hear appeals. This has crippled dispute settlement—cases can now be appealed into limbo, effectively allowing losing parties to avoid compliance. (3) Rising protectionism: The 2008 financial crisis and recent trade wars have seen increased use of tariffs and other barriers, undermining the spirit of WTO rules. (4) New issues: The WTO rules were designed for an era of goods trade. They do not adequately address digital trade, e-commerce, services, state-owned enterprises, or climate change. (5) China's role: China's state-capitalist system has challenged WTO rules designed for market economies. Issues like subsidies, intellectual property, and state-owned enterprises are difficult to address within existing frameworks. (6) Proliferation of regional agreements: The stalemate at the WTO has led countries to pursue bilateral and regional trade agreements (like the CPTPP, USMCA, RCEP), which may undermine the multilateral system. These challenges threaten the WTO's relevance and effectiveness.
principles.application: When analyzing the future of global trade, consider these challenges. The WTO is not static—it must adapt or risk irrelevance. Debates about WTO reform are central to discussions about the future of globalization.
principles.example: The U.S.-China trade war (2018-2020) was conducted largely outside WTO rules, with both countries imposing tariffs without WTO authorization. This highlighted the WTO's inability to constrain major powers and the fragility of the system.

image.alt: Diagram showing challenges facing WTO: Doha stalemate, Appellate Body blockage, protectionism, new issues
image.caption: Figure 10.4.9: The WTO faces significant challenges that threaten its effectiveness and relevance.

principles.principle: Regional Trade Agreements Complement and Compete with the WTO
principles.statement: While the WTO is the global framework for trade, many countries have also pursued regional trade agreements (RTAs)—preferential trade deals with specific partners. RTAs include free trade agreements (like USMCA, CPTPP), customs unions (like the EU), and economic partnerships. These agreements are allowed under WTO rules as exceptions to MFN, provided they cover substantially all trade and do not raise barriers to non-members. RTAs have proliferated, especially as the Doha Round stalled. They offer countries a way to achieve deeper integration than is possible at the multilateral level, addressing issues like investment, competition policy, and regulatory cooperation that are not covered by the WTO. However, RTAs also create complexity—different rules for different partners (the spaghetti bowl effect)—and can divert trade from more efficient non-members. They may also undermine the multilateral system by creating competing blocs. The relationship between RTAs and the WTO is complex: they can be building blocks toward global liberalization or stumbling blocks that fragment the trading system.
principles.application: When analyzing trade policy, consider both the WTO framework and regional agreements. A country may be part of multiple overlapping agreements, with different rules for different partners. This complexity affects trade patterns and business decisions.
principles.example: The United States is a member of the WTO, USMCA (with Canada and Mexico), and has bilateral agreements with many other countries. Each agreement has different rules of origin, tariff schedules, and dispute procedures, creating complexity for businesses.

image.caption: Figure 10.4.10: Regional trade agreements have proliferated, especially as multilateral negotiations have stalled.

worked_examples.title: Applying MFN and National Treatment

image.caption: Figure 10.4.11: Determine whether each scenario violates MFN or national treatment.

worked_examples.problem: For each scenario, determine whether it violates the WTO principle of most-favored-nation (MFN) or national treatment. If it violates, explain why. a) Country A imposes a 10% tariff on imports of cars from all countries. b) Country A imposes a 5% tariff on cars from Country B, but a 10% tariff on cars from Country C. c) Country A imposes a 10% sales tax on all cars sold, regardless of origin. d) Country A imposes a 10% sales tax on imported cars but only 5% on domestically produced cars. e) Country A signs a free trade agreement with Country B, eliminating tariffs on trade between them, while maintaining tariffs on imports from Country C.

step_by_step.explanation: Same tariff for all countries. This is consistent with MFN. No violation.
Different tariffs for different countries. This violates MFN unless there's an exception (like an FTA). If no FTA, Country C can complain that it's not receiving the same treatment as B.
Same sales tax on all cars. This is consistent with national treatment (no discrimination between domestic and imported). No violation.
Higher tax on imported cars violates national treatment. Once goods have entered the market, they must be treated no less favorably than domestic goods.
This is an FTA, which is an exception to MFN allowed under WTO rules, provided it meets conditions (covers substantially all trade, doesn't raise barriers to others). So no violation.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) OK. b) Violates MFN. c) OK. d) Violates national treatment. e) OK (FTA exception).
worked_examples.concept_applied: MFN requires equal treatment across countries; national treatment requires equal treatment between domestic and imported goods.

worked_examples.title: Understanding Dispute Settlement

image.caption: Figure 10.4.12: Trace a dispute through the WTO process.

worked_examples.problem: Country X believes Country Y has imposed tariffs that violate WTO commitments. a) What is the first step Country X should take? b) If consultations fail, what happens next? c) If the panel rules in favor of Country X, what must Country Y do? d) If Country Y fails to comply, what can Country X do? e) How has the blockage of the Appellate Body affected this process?

step_by_step.explanation: Country X should request consultations with Country Y. This is a mandatory first step to try to reach a negotiated solution without litigation.
If consultations fail, Country X can request that the WTO establish a dispute settlement panel. The panel, composed of independent experts, will hear the case and issue a ruling.
Country Y must bring its measures into compliance with WTO rules. It should have a reasonable period of time to do so.

If Y does not comply within the reasonable period, X can request authorization to retaliate by suspending concessions (imposing tariffs) equivalent to the damage caused. The WTO must authorize the retaliation.

With the Appellate Body blocked, either party can appeal a panel ruling and the appeal will be stuck in limbo (no judges to hear it). This effectively allows the losing party to avoid compliance indefinitely, as the ruling cannot be finalized. This has crippled the dispute settlement system.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Consultations. b) Panel established. c) Comply within reasonable period. d) Request authorization to retaliate. e) Appeals stuck, allowing non-compliance.
worked_examples.concept_applied: WTO dispute settlement provides a structured process, but the Appellate Body blockage has impaired its effectiveness.

worked_examples.title: Evaluating a Regional Trade Agreement

image.alt: Table comparing trade creation and trade diversion
image.caption: Figure 10.4.13: Evaluate whether a regional trade agreement is trade-creating or trade-diverting.

worked_examples.problem: Countries A and B form a free trade area, eliminating tariffs on trade between them. Before the agreement, Country A imported a good from Country C (the most efficient global producer) at a price of $\$100$, paying a 20% tariff ($\$20$) for total cost $\$120$. Country B produces the same good at $\$115$. After the agreement, Country A can import from Country B tariff-free at $\$115$. a) Does Country A switch its imports from C to B? b) Is this trade creation or trade diversion? c) What is the welfare effect on Country A? d) What is the welfare effect globally? e) How does this illustrate the potential downside of regional agreements?

step_by_step.explanation: Before: A imports from C at $\$120$ (including tariff). After: A can import from B at $\$115$ (no tariff). Since $115 < 120$, A will switch to importing from B.

This is trade diversion. A has switched from the most efficient global producer (C) to a less efficient producer (B) because of preferential treatment. Global resources are now allocated less efficiently.

A pays $\$115$ instead of $\$120$, so it gains $\$5$ per unit. However, it also loses tariff revenue ($\$20$ per unit) that it no longer collects. Net effect: gain of $5$ in lower price minus loss of $20$ in tariff revenue = -$15$ per unit. A is worse off by $\$15$ per unit.
C loses exports; B gains production; A's net loss is $15$ per unit. Globally, production shifts from lower-cost C to higher-cost B, reducing global efficiency. Global welfare decreases.

Regional agreements can cause trade diversion—shifting trade from efficient non-members to less efficient members. This reduces global welfare, even though it benefits the members in the agreement (in this case, A actually loses overall, but B gains). This is why WTO rules require that FTAs cover substantially all trade to minimize such effects.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Yes, switches to B. b) Trade diversion. c) A loses $\$15$ per unit. d) Global welfare decreases. e) Regional agreements can divert trade from efficient to inefficient sources.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Regional trade agreements can cause trade diversion, reducing global welfare even as they increase trade among members.

process_flow.description: A country negotiates accession, committing to WTO rules and tariff bindings.
process_flow.mechanism: Accession involves bilateral negotiations with existing members and commitments to reduce tariffs and reform trade-related policies. Once accepted, the country gains MFN treatment from all members.
process_flow.result: New member integrated into WTO system.

process_flow.description: WTO members periodically launch negotiating rounds to further liberalize trade.
process_flow.mechanism: Negotiations cover tariffs, non-tariff barriers, services, intellectual property, and new issues. Decisions are made by consensus. Successful rounds result in new agreements and commitments.

image.caption: Figure 10.4.15: Step 2 - Members negotiate new trade rules in ministerial conferences and negotiating rounds.

process_flow.description: Countries notify the WTO of trade policy changes and undergo periodic Trade Policy Reviews.
process_flow.mechanism: Transparency requirements ensure that other members can monitor compliance. The Trade Policy Review Mechanism provides peer review of members' trade policies.

process_flow.description: When members believe others have violated rules, they initiate dispute settlement.
process_flow.mechanism: Consultations, panels, and appeals lead to rulings. Losing parties must comply or face retaliation. The process is binding and enforceable.

process_flow.mechanism: Members debate reforms, launch new initiatives (e.g., e-commerce negotiations), and seek to address Appellate Body blockage. The system's resilience is tested.

summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is the international organization that sets the rules for global trade, provides a forum for negotiations, and resolves disputes between member countries. Established in 1995 as the successor to the GATT, it has 164 members accounting for over 98% of world trade. The WTO is built on core principles: most-favored-nation (MFN) treatment requiring equal treatment for all members; national treatment requiring equal treatment for imports after entry; reciprocity in negotiations; transparency of trade policies; and binding commitments on tariffs. The WTO's main functions include administering trade agreements, providing a forum for negotiations, monitoring national trade policies through the Trade Policy Review Mechanism, providing technical assistance, and resolving disputes. The dispute settlement mechanism is the WTO's crown jewel—a binding process involving consultations, panel rulings, appeals to the Appellate Body, and authorized retaliation. It has handled over 600 disputes and prevented many trade wars. The WTO also conducts negotiating rounds; the Uruguay Round (1986-94) created the WTO and extended rules to services and intellectual property. The current Doha Development Round, launched in 2001, has stalled. The WTO faces significant challenges: the Doha Round stalemate; the blockage of the Appellate Body by the U.S., crippling dispute settlement; rising protectionism and trade wars; new issues like digital trade and climate change not adequately covered; China's state-capitalist system challenging WTO rules; and the proliferation of regional trade agreements that may undermine the multilateral system. Regional trade agreements (RTAs) like FTAs and customs unions are allowed as exceptions to MFN but can create trade diversion—shifting trade from efficient non-members to less efficient members—reducing global welfare. Despite its challenges, the WTO remains the foundation of the global trading system, providing predictability, transparency, and a rules-based framework that has contributed to decades of trade expansion and economic growth. Understanding the WTO is essential for analyzing international trade governance, the benefits of multilateralism, and the future of globalization.
